Would it make sense to cache the lowercase versions of `s1` and `s2` and index into those instead?

This piece of code needs a microbenchmark, since I have no idea. I'm not sure how to do that off the top of my head though.
How about extracting all symbols from some mostly used type definitions and then apply `getSpellingSuggestion` randomly?

Maybe? One way to stress the system would be to have a scope that fills in all possible neighbours, so that the algorithm has to run on lots of candidates, all under the maximum distance cutoff.

I'm going to run the perf suite on this too, since all those projects compile with lots of errors now -- maybe enough of them are name resolution errors to notice a slowdown.
I‚Äôll give everyone until EOD to bikeshed this horribly vague name.
viva posix

Can we document why we're unconditionally handling this ourselves and not deferring to `string.toLocaleLowercase` (or `Intl.Collator`), as we do in `compareStringsCaseSensitiveUI`, where possible (namely what cases that fails to handle)?
https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/pull/36106/files#diff-66cec844e251a1918deb897eabca206bR1404 is this not good enough ?
It explains what's being done, but not why using locale lower case is insufficient.

diffHunk:

     */
    export function toFileNameLowerCase(x: string) {
        return fileNameLowerCaseRegExp.test(x) ?
            x.replace(fileNameLowerCaseRegExp, toLowerCase) :

comments.body: Is this windows specific (does this need to live in `sys` and keyed off of `process.os`), or is this also important on mac? And on windows and non-windows systems, does this potentially change with the system locale?

This is a feature of the standard Windows filesystem (NTFS). It's not affected by system locale - the upcase table is hardcoded into the filesystem. In theory, other case-insensitive filesystems could behave differently re: casing. 

I'm a lot less clear on the Mac OS system specifics but I just tried out creating some files on my Macbook, and a similar issue exists - (I,i) , (ƒ∞) and (ƒ±) are all distinct filenames even though the filesystem is case insensitive. Note this is slightly different than Windows which treats (ƒ∞,ƒ±) as equivalent. It's entirely possible `toLowerCase` does the right thing for the Mac scenario, I just haven't tried it out.
Is the behavior on Windows different if the active drive is backed by FAT32 instead of NTFS (eg, an old thumb drive)? Or do FAT and NTFS have the same filename case handling in windows?
I'm like 99.99% sure FAT32 behaves exactly the same but I'm speaking from memory.

This is what it looks like on node for Mac:

```sh
‚ùØ node
> "ƒ∞iÃáƒ±".toLowerCase()
'iÃáiÃáƒ±'
> "ƒ∞iÃáƒ±".toUpperCase()
'ƒ∞ƒ∞I'
```
We're interested in filesystem behavior (what's equivalent to what on disk) - `toLowerCase` and `toUpperCase` in the language are specified üòõ

Thanks orta for looking into that.
I don't think, we should depend on the os to determine how to get canonical file name at all.. Considering `ƒ∞ƒ±` as unique(that is not changing file casing for those) is right thing to do.. In worst cases we wont recognize that file with `ƒ∞` and `iÃá` are not same which would be really a small group. The `GetCanonicalFileName` is internal compiler thing that currently is based on if file system is case sensitive or not and we shouldn't change that fact. It is an ok trade off to do in my opinion

cc: @RyanCavanaugh  and @DanielRosenwasser to see if they agree.
Also we do not want to use `toUpperCase` since in most cases file name is lowercase so not having to store duplicate strings just for case swapping is more performant

> I don't think, we should depend on the os to determine how to get canonical file name at all

No, I'm not saying query the OS - i'm saying check `process.os` to see if the host is mac or windows (in `sys.ts`, as that's where we do things like that) to swap between a windows implementation of `toFileNameLowerCase` and a mac implementation of `toFileNameLowerCase`, since their handling of turkish i differs. As-is, this might fix turkish i on windows, but will potentially break it on mac, since our existing `toLowerCase` call _may have happened_ to already do the right thing for the mac's implementation of case-insensitivity.

Pretty much: we shouldn't break one platform to fix another, or only partially fix the issue on windows only - we should properly handle both.

The argument is pretty much that our discussion here has made it evident that, as it relates to filesystems, there isn't just `case sensitive` vs `case insensitive` - there's `case sensitive` vs `windows case insensitive` vs `mac case insensitive` (probably vs `linux bespoke filesystem case insensitive` but we care about that way, way less), and while the later two are they same in the ASCII range, they differ in some of the edge cases, as @minestarks pointed out. We should strive to handle them both.
This is probably just a convention I don't recognize, but why "right", rather than "reverse"?

Yep, I was modeling off of `Array.prototype.reduceRight`. Without a precedent of convention I would avoid using ‚Äúhanded‚Äù language as I imagine it‚Äôs somewhat dissonant to folks whose first written language is RTL.
How do you choose between for-of, for-increment, and `forEach`?
`arg => forEach(fs, f => f(arg)) || false`?

Yeah, that would work. I think I also have a tendency to implement abstractions with building blocks that are _less_ abstract than the function I‚Äôm implementing, if that makes sense. `or` and `forEach` are both fairly low-level atomic abstractions, so it makes sense to me that neither would depend on the other, but would rather be built with primitive loops. (I‚Äôve never been consciously aware of this thought process before now; it‚Äôs typically just driven by a vague intuition.)

I guess, in my mind, if `or` can straightforwardly be reduced to `forEach` it is higher-level.  `forEach` also seems like the sort of thing that might eventually be performance-tuned and it would be nice to pick up the benefits automatically.  I don't feel strongly about it though.
This is a pretty good example of what TS would now consider suspicious-enough code to error on. Making `e` optional would also have fixed this.
/raises eyebrow at name

It maps a map into a new map.

What more do you want. üòÑ

At least in V8 this causes the array to be considered "holey" and therefore it's not as optimized as packed arrays.
On the other hand repeatedly calling `push` needs to grow the backing store.

I'd say this is fine as is, as this function is only used in a single place in `generateTypes.ts`. So the holey array won't cause too much deoptimization where it's used. The alternative using `push` wouldn't be a problem either because the arrays are unlikely to contain more than a dozen elements.
You can pass a function that only takes `x`, right?
Do we really need this function in compiler? Can it be part of services\utilities instead?

This functions needs to be used in the typings installer and in tsserver; I couldn't find another file that was shared by them. services\utilities isn't involved in the typings installer and adding it introduced more errors because it needs references to e.g. Project
Would be easier to read if you just called `compareStrings` inside the loop -- then we wouldn't need a `compareStringsCaseSensitive` function and could just use `===` directly.
That's what this did before. However, that means we are evaluating the `ignoreCase` condition for each iteration of the loop. This saves a few cycles.
I would think that an indirect function call isn't any faster than an if?

I've actually removed `compareStrings` now. Comparisons need to be explicit and intentional:

- `compareValues` now only compares numbers
- `compareStringsCaseSensitive` compares strings using an ordinal case-sensitive comparison
- `compareStringsCaseSensitiveUI` compares strings using a dictionary-ordered case-sensitive comparison using the current UI locale
- `compareStringsCaseInsensitive` compares strings using an ordinal case-insensitive comparison
- `compareStringsCaseInsensitiveUI` compares strings using a dictionary-ordered case-insensitive comparison using the current UI locale
What's the file extension of something like `.gitconfig`?  If we decide that it has no file extension (because that's not really what dot means in that position) we just have to change `>=` to `>`.
I always think of those as files with just an extension. Not sure it matters in this case (e.g. if you have a file named `.html`, you probably want it treated as an HTML file.
`<||>` is much better name for this function bro
I'm sure I'm missing something, but how is this different from a for-of loop?

A `for-in` loop iterates over the keys of an object, while a `for-of` loop only works on an object implementing the iterator protocol. See [MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Guide/Iterators_and_Generators)
It's also supposedly identical to `Object.values`, which, much like `hasOwnProperty`, which we should probably check for the existence of and use if available.
so why do we have undefined file paths?
Answers from plugins may include them
would not that cause issues in other places as well, and should we just prune/sanitize the list first in these cases?
Why this change?
This avoids needing a closure for the second argument (if it is not an interpolation).

Is this overload order correct? Won't we just always pick the top one, since a `ReadonlyArray` will be compatible with it (so we'll never go down the list)? (Same comment on `singleOrMany`, `concatenate`, `sameFlatMap`, `sameMap`, and `filter`)
The more-specific overload should go first -- `T[]` is more specific than `ReadonlyArray` since it contains everything `ReadonlyArray` has, plus mutators.
Good call! üëç
@mihailik You could make a pull request updating both `configureNightly.ts` and `core.ts`, but please don't revert it back to where we had multiple `versionMajorMinor` declarations.
That's a great idea! I'll try to work on it soon and we can compare likes for likes.
also remove the check in `toKey` — `keyMapper ? keyMapper(path) : path`.
This is used exactly ONCE. Is it worth extracting like that -- from performance, code clarity or any other perspective?

It's generally useful to factor generic code out of a more specific context. That way you don't have to worry about the specifics of how an array is converted to a set, and only have to worry about the actual problem domain.
Is this a potential breaking change if anyone else is using matchFiles? Should depth be added as the final param?
This is `/* @internal */`. (See comment at top of the enclosing namespace)

What was the reason for intentionally breaking the signature here (the only answer above to the question is that it is supposedly private)? Regardless of the `/* @internal */` comment this method is exported (without an underscore or other indication of it being private) on the main export (e.g. `import { matchFiles } from 'typescript'`). 

This is definitely a breaking change and makes life difficult for tooling that must support both 2.4 and 2.5.  See https://github.com/tildeio/broccoli-typescript-compiler/issues/49.

That escalated quickly!

Whence has this change come from?

This shouldn't actually change the value. I needed to access just the `major.minor` version in a test, so I made a variable just for that, and wrote `version` in terms of it so they wouldn't get out-of-sync.

Ah, see that now, thanks a lot!

I wonder whether moving complexity out of testing code into the compiler is worthy. Especially, now it's surfaced in the API in a confusing way (can we still assume normal version is dot-joined numbers?). And of course readability and text-searchability suffers.

versionMajorMinor was required in several places (not just tests), but previously we were parsing it out of `version`. Figured it would be better to construct `version` from `versionMajorMinor` than the other way around.
Why not `ReadonlyArray<U>`?

We always create a fresh array. If the caller wants a readonly array they can type it that way.
Can't just change this one to ReadonlyArray because `services/types.ts` currently uses mutable arrays. We should change that separately. #16312
For my own edification, does this have some advantage over calling `concat`?
Cute.
Does the line ending matter?  I'm not sure how it changed, but I can revert it.
Don't see any reason to allow an `undefined` parameter since the function will always fail in that case.
If we ever turn on `--strictNullChecks` there may be cases where `value` may be typed `undefined`.

If you want the Map shim to have support for keys/values/entries iterators, take a look at https://gist.github.com/rbuckton/06d2c79bea46778f9e8bbeca77292087. That way there is less differentiation between what we need out of a native Map and what our shim provides.
Kind of funny that the `Identifier` constructor needs to take a `SyntaxKind`
Who knows, we could eventually have different kind's of `Identifier` nodes.

I understand this is not part of this change. but can we replace this with a check at the use site, and other wise use the normal loop. optionally have two implementations. it would not make sens to have a function call just to return `>`

For really long comments, there's https://gist.github.com ;)
what changes on this line? Is it the line ending?

It's line ending. This line ends with just an `LF` in master.

Which is strange, because we have a lint rule covering this which is not triggering.
Does it only detect _extra_ line endings? It just fired for me when I had an extra.
are there any other places that should use this function? I think we use objects as maps quite a lot.

There are a lot of places that use code like this -- just search for `] ||` -- but they seem to be using numeric IDs (so are safe from default properties) or are safe for other reasons.
I'm also currently looking into using Maps as maps.
what's the diff here?
@rakatyal just remembered your tslint rule would have issues with this because it can't distinguish between `ts.Symbol` and `Symbol`
From the code, isnt  the default case is unknown?
I don't think this temp is needed for readability or efficiency.
Why no hasOwnProperty check here?
It should have. Thanks for pointing out.
doesn't this make more sense in sys.ts ?
Most of our other path logic exists in core.ts.
Any specific reason for these values?

It is a formal way to specify the offsets to each extension in `allSupportedExtensions`, and is used to disambiguate between `file.ts` and `file.d.ts` (or also `file.js` with `-allowJs`) in the same directory. This could have just been constant values, but I felt this was more descriptive.

this is necessary to skip `host` argument in the `trace` function

For an empty string key, you'll always use the non-localized message unless you use `message.key in localizedDiagnosticMessages`. Though, that would be the most ridiculous edge case I may have ever brought up.
use `for-of`

`lastIndexOf` with start position 0 here works as `startsWith` since it searches backwards starting from given position
Ah, so it's a faster check.
We use some stuff like this in the harness - @yuit was questioning the logic a week ago. Not sure if the problem persists.

i think we should only have one lib file with some details inside on when declarations are relevant, e.g. decorators/attribute annotations that say if this declaration applies to the current compilation or not.
managing multiple files has been a hassle.
@mhegazy I agree on that. Also, should we make sure that the target exist first? or we are guarantee to have default target as there was a problem in the harness when target isn't specified
Can we just use JSON here?  And polyfill for the one host that doesn't support it?
so I would do a check if JSON is defined, and use it to escape, and fallback to escapestring otherwise. other than that the change looks good to me.

'distinct'.

'deduplicate' indicates you are mutating in the array in place.   'distinct' is the linq name for getting back the set of unique elements.

`compareValues('1', 1)` computes a BCT of `{}` and succeeds without complaint, see #360
